subject: üîí Unlock Your NYC Tech Job Strategy ‚Äì Interview Skills, Live Demos & More!
body:
Hi everyone,

We‚Äôre excited to invite you to a special in-person event hosted by the MS
Admissions Ambassadors at the NYU Center for Data Science, featuring the
NYC Tech Interview Squad ‚Äì a group of data scientists and engineers
dedicated to helping students navigate the job market by sharing insider
hiring insights from ‚Äúthe other side of the table.‚Äù

üìÖ Date: Friday, October 3, 2025
üìç Venue: CDS Open Space (7th Floor)
üïì Time: 4:30 PM ‚Äì 6:30 PM
üçï Bonus: Free food provided!
What to expect:

This dynamic and hands-on session includes:

   -

   Resume red flags, how to market yourself effectively on LinkedIn
   -

   Behavioral and technical interview prep tips
   -

   A live interview demo
   -

   Breakout table rotations for live resume reviews, mock oral interviews,
   and a technical drill
   -

   Potentially alumni networking

You do not have to be actively job-hunting to benefit from this session ‚Äì
whether you're building your materials, exploring options, or just curious,
you‚Äôll gain practical insights from professionals who‚Äôve been on both ends
of the hiring process.

RSVP HERE: https://cdsfall2025nyctechinterviewsquad.eventbrite.com *Alumni,
please RSVP by October 1 to gain visitor access.
Help us tailor the content ‚Äì fill out this quick survey
<https://forms.gle/kFM5w7Emxa4KVbRS7> by Sept 26, 11:59 PM

Note: This event is for CDS Alumni and MS students only.
Best,
CDS MS Admissions Ambassadors
cdsmsambassadors@nyu.edu

subject: CDS Grad Welcome (Back) Event - September 12th, 4:30-6:30pm
[Important] CDS House Rules, Printing Access & CDS Library
body:
Hello MS Students,

Please see information/reminders below regarding CDS House Rules,
printing access,
and the CDS library. Note: this information is also available on the FAQ
page of the CDS Grad Student Portal
<https://sites.google.com/nyu.edu/cdsgradportal/faqs-cds-survival-guide>.

üëâ *CDS House Rulesüëà
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1CaU40hcKD88X_WHag_jHdlRVztvLCwzhWRojHjK11r4/edit?usp=sharing>
*This
serves as a guide for how we use and share our spaces as a community,
including things like:

   - CDS floor access (hours, restricted areas)
   - Use of the 7th floor open space
   - Kitchen and refrigerator etiquette
   - Prayer/meditation room expectations

Thanks for helping us keep our CDS spaces welcoming, respectful, and
organized!

*Printing at CDS*
To access the printers on the 2nd and 7th floors of CDS, you will need a
CIMS account
<https://cims.nyu.edu/webapps/content/systems/userservices/accounts>.

   - For Master's students, please request a CIMS account through this form
   - http://cims.nyu.edu/webapps/account_requests/new. If you will not be
   using a CIMS account while you are a CDS student, please do not request one.

Once you have a CIMS account, information on how to access the printers can
be found in the CDS Printing, Scanning, & Copying Guide
<https://drive.google.com/file/d/1jK4Pinja-fIDoLkUkqmZYRkIukNcO9AF/view?usp=sharing>
.

*CDS Library*
The CDS Library is officially up and running!

You can find the library in the glass case by the 7th floor reception area
and reach out to Joshua for the checking out/checking in processes. Please
note you can only take a book out for 48 hours at a time. In the event you
need the book longer please check it in and then check it back out or
coordinate with Joshua in advance if you need more time. This will help us
control the inventory, ensure quality control, and that all students have a
chance to use the books.

Please visit nyu536.libib.com and create a patron account, by clicking
"Need Password". *You must use your NYU Net ID to access the system, no
other email address will work!*

**You can still check books out of the CDS Library without an account, but
please note there are several advantages to having an account such as:
holding books, checking inventory, ability to see book summary, etc.**

Feel free to also reach out if you would like to recommend any books to be
added!

*Reminder: These resources are available to CDS students only. Please do
not forward them to others.*

Best,
Francheska

-- 
Francheska Jimenez, M.A.
Assistant Director of Academic & Student Affairs
Center for Data Science
E: fj6@nyu.edu
T: 212-998-3358
60 Fifth Ave., 7th floor
New York, NY 10011

My office is a *S**A**FE ZONE* for individuals of all ethnicities,
abilities, religions, sexual orientations, and gender identities.
*gender pronouns
<https://www.nyu.edu/life/global-inclusion-and-diversity/learning-and-development/toolkits/pronouns.html>:
she, her, hers*

subject: CDS Weekly | Volume 6, Issue 1
body:
NYU



### CDS WEEKLY | VOLUME 6, ISSUE 1 | SEPTEMBER 2, 2025



Important Dates & Reminders:

  * DS-GA 1009/CPT Guidelines for CDS Graduate Students:

    *
Internship Course and¬†CPT¬†Guidelines (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/5a118y). At the latest, the completed package of required documents must be submitted to Tina Lam (tina.lam@nyu.edu) for approval by the first week of classes of the semester of enrollment.
    * International students requiring CPT approval must submit the required documents at least 3 weeks before their start date or by the first week of classes (whichever is earlier).

  * Tuesday, September 2: Fall 2025 classes begin
  * Monday, September 15:

    * Last day to add/drop on Albert
    * Last day of waiting lists
    * Last day to drop course and receive 100% refund
    * Last day to drop course and not receive a "W" (withdrawal) on your transcript.

  * Monday, October 13: Fall Break





### UPCOMING CDS EVENTS:


Join us on Friday, September 13th from 5-6:30pm in the CDS Open Space for our annual Welcome (Back) Event for graduate students! Catch up with returning classmates and get to know the incoming cohort. There will be dinner, drinks, music, board games, and ping pong!. Registration is required to attend via Eventbrite:
https://cdsfall2025gradwelcome.eventbrite.com (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/l3118y)

Note: This event is open to CDS graduate students only. Please make sure to have your NYU ID with the CDS sticker ready at check-in.

CILVR Seminar: Kyunghyun Cho (All) | 9/3/2025, 3:30-5PM | CDS Open Space

Alumni Career Talk: Aryan Jain (MS/PhD) | 9/5/2025, 4:30-6:30PM | CDS Open Space

Last Summer Internship Panel (MS) | 9/8/2025, 2:30-3:45PM | CDS Open Space

What the heck does a data scientist do? (UG) | 9/9/2025, 5-6PM | CDS Open Space

CILVR Seminar: Yann Lecun (All) | 9/10/2025, 2:30-4PM | CDS Open Space

Research 101 (UG) | 9/10/2025, 5-6PM | CDS Open Space

MaD Seminar: Eshaan Nichani (All) | 9/11/2025, 2-3PM | 60FA 150

I know what you did last summer - Internship Panel (UG) | 9/11/2025, 5-6PM | CDS Open Space

CDS Grad Welcome Event (MS/PhD) | 9/12/2025, 4:30-6:30PM | CDS Open Space

CDS Undegrad Welcome Back Event (UG) | 9/19/2025, 1-3PM | CDS Open Space



### CDS CLUB NEWS:

### CAREER TIP OF THE WEEK:

Your resume: When an application reviewer is looking over your resume, make it easy for them to understand who you are and what you know. If you have online profiles like GitHub, LinkedIn, social media, or even your own personal website, put it on your resume. Don't make them have to search long and hard for you online if they want to know more! Include the tech that you used, impacts you made, and relevant things that you would bring to the table. Recruiters should be able to skim your resume and understand what role you want and what your experience level is. Check out the Career Advising page on the CDS Student Portal for more helpful resources.

### NYU NEWS & RESOURCES:

@NYU GSAS

  *
Fall Welcome (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/1v218y)
| September 5, 5-7PM ET, Amity Hall

    * Join the Master's College for the annual Fall Welcome, an event to kick off the fall semester! This is a great way to meet and mingle with your fellow GSAS students, connect with the Master's College, and have a fun evening.

  *
Mets v. Padres Baseball Game (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/ho318y)
| September 16, 7:10PM ET, Amity Hall

    * Join GSAS for an evening of food, drinks, and meaningful conversations with fellow students, student organizations, and key NYU departments that will support you throughout your journey here. This event is open to all students, and offers a wonderful opportunity to connect with both new and returning GSAS peers of all backgrounds.

  *
GSAS Multicultural Welcome (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/xg418y)
| September 9, 5:30-7:30PM ET, Silverstein Lounge

    * Ready for a thrilling Mets vs. Padres showdown? Join the Master's College to see the San Diego Padres at New York Mets Citi Field in Flushing, NY! Tickets are limited and will be chosen at random.

  *
One on One Writing Advisor appointments (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/d9418y)

    * GSAS master's students can sign up for free, one-on-one, 20-minute appointments with a writing advisor. Appointments can be in-person or over Zoom. Students can send materials they would like reviewed and a request for an appointment to gsas.writing@nyu.edu. Students are guaranteed an advisor appointment within 3 to 5 business days of asking for an appointment.

  *
Graduate Fellowship Finder (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/t1518y)

    * Students seeking external fellowships opportunities should visit the Fellowship Finder. This database allows students to easily sort by field, citizenship, stage of study, and more.



@NYU Wasserman

  *
The Value of Small Talk in the U.S. (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/9t618y)
| September 3, 11AM-12PM ET, Virtual

    * How can you talk to strangers during a networking event or during the first minutes of an interview? You can start by having a casual conversation. In the U.S., this is often referred to as "small talk" and it's generally a helpful way to start a conversation. In our first event of the International Student Career Development Series, join a panel of NYU alumni, staff and students for a discussion on how to practice small talk in the U.S. and how it can impact your career.

  *
Grad Level Resumes and Cover Letters (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/pm718y)
| September 3, 12PM-1PM ET, Wasserman USQ Presentation Room A

    * Attend this workshop to help you identify tangible skills and strengths that you've gained through graduate level study, while participating in a series of interactive exercises that will allow you to articulate these skills in your resume and cover letter.

  *
Beyond the Professoriate: How to Use the PhD Training Platform in Your Job Searchn (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/5e818y)
| September 3, 12PM-12:45PM ET, Virtual

    * Now more than ever, PhDs work in a variety of career fields, leveraging their education and training to build meaningful careers after their degree or postdoc. So what can you do today to set yourself up for a successful job search? In this webinar, you'll learn how to make the most out of the PhD Career Training Platform.

  *
Interstride: Introduction to the International Student Career Tool (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/l7818y)
| September 3, 4PM-5PM ET, Virtual

    * Join the Interstride team for an introduction to this powerful new resource that helps students navigate the immigration journey, find jobs from international-student friendly employers, and access country guides supporting job searches across the globe.

  *
From Classroom to Career: Empowering First-Generation Graduate Students (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/1z918y)
| September 4, 12PM-1PM ET, Virtual

    * Navigating graduate school often feels like learning a secret language, especially for first-generation graduate students. Join us to unlock the "hidden curriculum" - those unspoken rules and essential career strategies that aren't in any syllabus. This event is designed to empower you with insider knowledge, helping you confidently map out your professional future and truly make the most of your graduate degree. Don't miss this opportunity to connect, learn, and gain a significant advantage in your academic and career journey.

  *
Preparing for a Career Fair (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/hsa28y)
| September 4, 2:30PM-3:30PM ET, Virtual

    * Find out more about Student Employment at NYU and how you can search for on-campus jobs! We'll be giving an overview of what we do and discuss the types of on-campus jobs (including Federal Work Study), how to use Handshake to search for jobs, and how to contact a career coach for resume/cover letter review!

  *
First-Generation Professional Development Program (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/xkb28y)
| Application Deadline: Friday, September 5th, 2025

    * Calling all first-generation sophomores, juniors, and seniors! The application deadline for the First-Generation Professional Development Program has been extended to Friday, September 5th. This fall semester cohort program aims to provide students with the skills, knowledge, and resources needed for a successful internship and job search process.

  *
Wasserman 101 for Grad Life (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/ddc28y)
| September 6, 11AM-12PM ET, Virtual

    * Learn about the useful career resources, specifically for graduate students, offered by the NYU Wasserman Center for Career Development.

  *
Ask a Peer: Small Talk in the U.S. (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/t5c28y)
| September 9, 1PM-2PM ET, Wasserman USQ, Presentation Room A

    * As part of our Ask the Expert Series, learn from your fellow students as you practice small talk typical in the workplace and other professional spaces. Build your confidence, expand your network, and find answers to your most important career questions through peer-to-peer advice and interactive activities in a relaxed setting.

  *
Undergrad Level Resumes (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/9xd28y)
| September 9, 3PM-4PM ET, Wasserman USQ, Presentation Room A

    * This introductory workshop will go over what kind of information to include on your resume, how to write about your experience, and formatting rules. This workshop is for students who have never written a resume before, or for those who need a reminder about basic guidelines.

  *
CaseCoach: Case Interview Foundations (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/pqe28y)
| September 9, 5PM-6:30PM ET, Virtual

    * In this session, you'll learn how to approach the case interview - common to the selection process for management consulting firms and other top employers around the world. This class is designed to get students started with preparation by familiarizing them with the key skills that case interviewers are seeking in candidates.



@NYU University Life (CMEP/LGBTQ+ Center)

  *
First Year Queers & Allies (FYQA) Information Session (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/5if28y)
| September 3, 1-2PM ET, Kimmel 602

    * First Year Queers & Allies (FYQA) gives incoming first year and transfer students at NYU the opportunity to build community with their peers, engage in service-learning within the larger NYC community, and develop themselves as leaders. Come to the info session to learn more about joining the cohort!

  *
Grad Student Social (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/lbg28y)
| September 4, 4-6PM ET, Rebel Restaurant & Bar

    * Kick off the academic year at our Grad Student Social, hosted by the Center for Multicultural Education and Programs and Grad Life. Join us at Rebel Restaurant & Bar! Meet other students, enjoy Haitian cuisine, and have a drink--on us.

  *
CMEP Around the City: Wing on Wo & Co. (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/13g28y)
| September 9, 3-5PM ET

    * Join the Center for Multicultural Education and Programs to visit the oldest shop in Chinatown, Wing on Wo & Co., and learn about how the owners support community-based initiatives and reinterpret tradition through an Asian American lens.

  *
Apply to First Year Queers & Allies (FYQA) (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/hwh28y)
| Deadline: September 10, 12PM ET

    * MindfulNYU hosts a wide offering of
FREE yoga and meditation classes (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/xoi28y)
throughout the week during the academic year. All classes are open to students, faculty, and staff with a current and valid NYU ID.

  *
Quench: Spill the Tea with Teagan (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/dhj28y)
| September 10, 12:30-2PM ET, Kimmel 602

    * Quench is the LGBTQ+ Center's monthly free lunch series connecting students to NYU and NYC resources. For the first Quench of the year, come meet Teagan Rabuano, the new Director of the LGBTQ+ Center! This is a space for all members of the NYU community to ask questions, share feedback, and discuss the Center's upcoming priorities and initiatives. Whether you're curious about what's ahead or have ideas of your own, we want to hear from you. Tea (of course!) and lunch will be provided.

  *
First-Generation Student Mixer (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/t9j28y)
| September 10, 4-6PM ET, Kimmel 804/5

    * Learn about how you can get involved and thrive as a first-gen student at NYU and mingle with one another. Connect with student-led organizations like the First-Generation Low-Income Partnership (FLIP), meet the team from Proud to Be First, and learn about the FOCUS mentorship program.

  *
Love Wins Food Pantry NYC (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/91k28y)

    * Love Wins NYC is a queer-centric and volunteer-led effort to address food insecurity in NYC. Love Wins distributes fresh and free produce to New Yorkers in locations across the city every month. They are always looking for donations and volunteers to help promote food justice, particularly for the LGBTQ+ immigrant community.



@NYU Global Spiritual Life

  * Walking Meditation to Pier 45 with MindfulNYU | September 15, 10-11:15AM

    * Begin your week with connection and join our walking meditation! We will meet outside the GCASL building and begin our contemplative walk to Pier 45. Walking together, we will be invited into a combination of mindfulness practices that foster connection, curiosity, and community. No experience required--just bring comfortable shoes and an open heart. If you have any questions, please reach out to mindfulness@nyu.edu.

  * MindfulNYU Classes

    * MindfulNYU hosts a wide offering of
FREE yoga and meditation classes (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/pul28y)
throughout the week during the academic year. All classes are open to students, faculty, and staff with a current and valid NYU ID.



@NYU Office of Global Services

  *
Passport Drive for US Citizens (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/5mm28y)
| September 26, StudentLink

    * Apply for or renew your US passport! The NYU Office of Global Services is offering Passport Acceptance events in partnership with the New York Passport Agency. This aims to help NYU community members get their US travel document, especially students planning to study abroad in the near future.

  *
English Conversation & Culture (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/lfn28y)
| Every Wednesday, 4-5PM, Kimmel 704

    * This interactive and informative series will explore topics like American academic culture, idioms and slang, and professional English conversation. It's a welcoming safe space for everyone to learn and practice--no need for notebooks or laptops, just bring yourself!



@NYU Libraries

  * Finding Non-English Language Materials at NYU and Beyond

    * NYU Libraries collects materials in more than 20 languages in addition to English, but finding them can be tricky. This class will give you tips on how to unearth these as well as the other non-English resources available to you beyond NYU Libraries.
    *
September 3, 12-1PM ET, Virtual (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/17n28y)
    *
September 10, 12-1PM ET, Bobst 619 (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/h0o28y)

  *
Introduction to Engineering Resources for Graduate Students (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/xsp28y)
| September 3, 2-3PM ET, Dibner 433

    * Are an engineering graduate student interested in learning more about the engineering resources available at NYU Libraries? Join us at Dibner Library for a workshop all about the engineering resources to support your research!

  *
Climate Action Mixer with Plant Meditation and Plant Giveaway (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/dlq28y)
| September 3, 6-7PM ET, Bobst 745

    * Join the Office of Sustainability and NYU Libraries for a climate action mixer! Participate in a 30-minute meditation where we will engage our senses and practice focused attention using plants, offering gratitude to the natural world. Aftewards, enjoy plant-based snacks while getting to know peers and friends who are interested in environmental issues and combatting climate change. Plants will be provided as giveaways for the meditation.

  *
Grad Student Open House at NYU Libraries (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/tdr28y)
| September 9, 6-7PM ET, Bobst Second Floor North Reading Room

    * Welcome to the Libraries! Drop in during our Open House with subject liaisons and other library specialists to learn about the variety of resources available as you launch your graduate journey at NYU. Light refreshments and scheduled raffle giveaways will be provided. Hosted by NYU Libraries and Grad Life.

  *
NYU Libraries Classes (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/95r28y)

    * Free courses ranging from Data Visualization with Tableau to Data Wrangling in R and Python for Harvesting Data on the Web to Writing a Data Management Plan for Grant Applications.



@NYU Writing Center

  *
Writing Workshops (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/pys28y)

    * Need help with your writing? (We all do!) Need help organizing an essay? Want to make your sentences clearer and more concise? Unsure of where to start with articulating a research problem? This semester, the Expository Writing Program at NYU is offering a set of remote and in person writing / research workshops for all undergraduates and MAs.



@NYU Entrepreneurial Institute

  *
How to Start a Startup at NYU (https://t.e2ma.net/click/hobcqh/dt03qtsf/5qt28y)
| September 4, 12:30-1:30PM ET, Leslie E-Lab

    * Curious about startups? Have an idea for a new venture? Already working on one, but need help and/or funding? Learn how NYU helps founders become the next generation of startup leaders. Meet members of the Entrepreneurial Institute team, and learn how to start a startup at NYU, and all the programming, events, resources and funding opportunities that exist to support and accelerate NYU entrepreneurs.

###     END.

subject: 2025-26 CDS Locker Request (Due: August 18th)
body:
Dear Students,

If you would like to request a locker space at CDS, *please complete this
form <https://forms.gle/XZwzbVzDY87MhUzE8>
(https://forms.gle/XZwzbVzDY87MhUzE8 <https://forms.gle/XZwzbVzDY87MhUzE8>)

Note: Please be aware that requests are not guaranteed as we have a limited

free to contact me if you have any questions.

Best,

subject: üìù [Response Requested] Share Your Ideas for MSDS Events & Opportunities!
[Student Opportunity] APPLICATIONS FOR FALL 2025 PARAGON POLICY FELLOWSHIP NOW OPEN!
body:
Dear Students,

Please see below an opportunity that may be of interest to you.

Best,
Francheska

---

Are you a student interested in the societal impacts of science and
technology? Apply to become a Fall 2025 Paragon Policy Fellow and work at
the forefront of tech policy with state and local governments across the US!

Paragon is a unique opportunity for students to explore and gain experience
in tech policy work while making meaningful contributions to their local
and state governments. By dedicating just 10 hours a week to researching
and working on policy briefs, past fellows have gained experience on
projects like AI-supported language access, broadband access, ethical
technology procurement standards, and third-party cybersecurity risk
management.

Paragon is a flexible, project-based experience tailored to fit your busy
semester schedule. The program will run from Friday, September 26th, to
Friday, December 19th, and all fellows and project leads will receive a
stipend of $500.

Applications are now open on Airtable
<https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__airtable.com_appmkvSiORszz5i5k_pagItVzXaicgbWZwJ_form&d=DwMFaQ&c=slrrB7dE8n7gBJbeO0g-IQ&r=xLdFh0CxQ8L1Hmuangirog&m=vcdufr6_L1iYjiR83nHmsJ4_wnnQUhP5cYjplTeLYIy0OdXarMLPmlfxiYyEnuLv&s=3HLcMmRRHaQ6S6CYFP7u4U6xK9Dn_IT1FNAgtlwA07M&e=>
 until September 5th, 2025!

To learn more, visit our website for FAQs and past projects at
paragonfellowship.org

subject: Window shop at tomorrow's Data Science Student Project Swap Meet
body:
Hi All:

This is my final reminder for tomorrow's student project swap meet. Pop in
during the two hour window and learn about the work that your fellow
students are doing. You may even find a connection or an opportunity to
collaborate and work on something exciting!

Register Here
<https://www.eventbrite.com/e/student-data-science-project-swap-meet-tickets-1734535565569?aff=oddtdtcreator>

The Swap Meet will be open for 2 hours (12-2pm on Friday 10/3). Attendees
are not required to be at the Swap Meet for the full 2 hours, like any swap
meet, you can come in at any time during this 2 hour window, explore the
tables to see what interests you.

subject: CDS Reseach Opportunity Session: Monday 9/29
body:
*Research Session with Catalina Canizares - Arcadia*
*Research Description: *We want to develop of a data system (and related
analytic and artistic products) that integrates existing suicide-related
datasets with educational, environmental, neighborhood, and other
policy-related data, using California as a ‚Äúproof of concept‚Äù in advance of
a national system. We plan to leverage the California Healthy Kids Survey
(CHKS) and braid that rich dataset with, for example, data from the
California Department of Education (CDE), the California Department of
Health Care Services, and the Stanford Education Data Archive (SEDA).

We need a student with abilities to curate and clean data to be merged to
the data system. As well as a student that feels comfortable working with R
and the tidyverse, that is eager to learn how to build R packages, and that
feels comfortable with data cleaning instead of data modeling.
*When: *12:30-1:30pm
*Where: *CDS 7th Floor Open Space (60 5th Avenue b/t 12th and 13th street)
*Audience: CDS MS and Undergraduate students*
Register Here
<https://www.eventbrite.com/e/faculty-research-session-catalina-canizares-tickets-1632899689929?aff=oddtdtcreator>*
(Please
use your NYU email address)*

-- 
Timothy Baker
Associate Director of Academic and Student Affairs
Center for Data Science
New York University
timothybaker@nyu.edu
212-998-3097
https://cds.nyu.edu/

subject: Research Opportunities for Next Week (Week of 9/29)
body:
Hi All,

If you are looking for research opportunities be sure to come to the
sessions next week!

*Monday 9/29:*
*Research Session with Catalina Canizares - Arcadia*
*Research Description: *We want to develop of a data system (and related
analytic and artistic products) that integrates existing suicide-related
datasets with educational, environmental, neighborhood, and other
policy-related data, using California as a ‚Äúproof of concept‚Äù in advance of
a national system. We plan to leverage the California Healthy Kids Survey
(CHKS) and braid that rich dataset with, for example, data from the
California Department of Education (CDE), the California Department of
Health Care Services, and the Stanford Education Data Archive (SEDA).

We need a student with abilities to curate and clean data to be merged to
the data system. As well as a student that feels comfortable working with R
and the tidyverse, that is eager to learn how to build R packages, and that
feels comfortable with data cleaning instead of data modeling.
*When: *12:30-1:30pm
*Where: *CDS 7th Floor Open Space (60 5th Avenue b/t 12th and 13th street)
*Audience: CDS MS and Undergraduate students*
Register Here
<https://www.eventbrite.com/e/faculty-research-session-catalina-canizares-tickets-1632899689929?aff=oddtdtcreator>*
(Please
use your NYU email address)*

*Tuesday 9/30:*
*Research Session with Marie Bragg (Dept of Population Health) and Emily
Balcetis (Dept of Psychology)*
*Marie Bragg: *We are investigating food marketing on social media, the
prevalence of dangerous "challenges" on social media, how visual attention
to food ads impact calorie consumption in adolescents, and are creating a
database of food company donations

*Emily Balcetis: *We‚Äôre aiming to develop a computer vision algorithm
trained on photographic data from U.S. neighborhoods, specifically
comparing areas with high vs. low levels of measured racial prejudice
(e.g., based on aggregated survey or behavioral data at the ZIP code
level). Our goal is to train a machine learning model to identify and
differentiate the visual features that are predictive of high- vs.
low-prejudice neighborhoods. These features would likely carry varying
degrees of predictive weight‚Äîe.g., a Confederate flag might be highly
diagnostic of a high-prejudice area, while a porch swing might carry a more
ambiguous signal. We plan to provide the labeled image dataset, with
training data sourced from ZIP codes categorized along the prejudice
dimension.
*When: *12:30-1:30pm
*Where: *CDS 7th Floor Open Space (60 5th Avenue b/t 12th and 13th street)
*Audience: CDS MS and Undergraduate students*
Register Here
<https://www.eventbrite.com/e/faculty-research-session-marie-bragg-and-emily-balcetis-tickets-1734907106859?aff=oddtdtcreator>*
(Please
use your NYU email address)*

-- 
Timothy Baker
Associate Director of Academic and Student Affairs
Center for Data Science
New York University
timothybaker@nyu.edu
212-998-3097
https://cds.nyu.edu/
